items.title:
New post: nanochat miniseries v1

The correct way to think about LLMs is that you are not optimizing...
items.content:
New post: nanochat miniseries v1

The correct way to think about LLMs is that you are not optimizing for a single specific model but for a family models controlled by a single dial (the compute you wish to spend) to achieve monotonically better results. This allows you to do careful science of scaling laws and ultimately this is what gives you the confidence that when you pay for "the big run", the extrapolation will work and your money will be well spent. For the first public release of nanochat my focus was on end-to-end pipeline that runs the whole LLM pipeline with all of its stages. Now after YOLOing a few runs earlier, I'm coming back around to flesh out some of the parts that I sped through, starting of course with pretraining, which is both computationally heavy and critical as the foundation of intelligence and knowledge in these models.

After locally tuning some of the hyperparameters, I swept out a number of models fixing the FLOPs budget. (For every FLOPs target you can train a small model a long time, or a big model for a short time.) It turns out that nanochat obeys very nice scaling laws, basically reproducing the Chinchilla paper plots:

Which is just a baby version of this plot from Chinchilla:
Very importantly and encouragingly, the exponent on N (parameters) and D (tokens) is equal at ~=0.5, so just like Chinchilla we get a single (compute-independent) constant that relates the model size to token training horizons. In Chinchilla, this was measured to be 20. In nanochat it seems to be 8!

Once we can train compute optimal models, I swept out a miniseries from d10 to d20, which are nanochat sizes that can do 2**19 ~= 0.5M batch sizes on 8XH100 node without gradient accumulation. We get pretty, non-itersecting training plots for each model size.

Then the fun part is relating this miniseries v1 to the GPT-2 and GPT-3 miniseries so that we know we're on the right track. Validation loss has many issues and is not comparable, so instead I use the CORE score (from DCLM paper). I calculated it for GPT-2 and estimated it for GPT-3, which allows us to finally put nanochat nicely and on the same scale:
The total cost of this miniseries is only ~$100 (~4 hours on 8XH100). These experiments give us confidence that everything is working fairly nicely and that if we pay more (turn the dial), we get increasingly better models.

TLDR: we can train compute optimal miniseries and relate them to GPT-2/3 via objective CORE scores, but further improvements are desirable and needed. E.g., matching GPT-2 currently needs ~$500, but imo should be possible to do <$100 with more work.

Full post with a lot more detail is here:
https://t.co/na8zVLqWLf
And all of the tuning and code is pushed to master and people can reproduce these with scaling_laws .sh and miniseries .sh bash scripts.

items.title:
‚ú® I used Claude Code to one-shot a üíÅ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Karen Bot

When we walk or drive around we come across a lot...
items.content:
‚ú® I used Claude Code to one-shot a üíÅ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Karen Bot

When we walk or drive around we come across a lot of things here that could be improved in terms of public infrastructure

Roads near us have lots of potholes, there's municipal waste bins here that someone put on fire 6 months ago, and they're all melted away and still not replaced, and the roadside mirror at a dangerous crossing suddenly disappeared so now when you wanna turn in there you might get because so many blindspots

When we emailed the city council about the holes in the road, they were actually fixed 3 days later (very fast!), so it does work to contact them, they just need to know what to fix and I don't think many other people report stuff here

It's annoying to keep emailing them, so I made a page that me and gf can use to describe the problem, attach a photo, set a point on the map where it is, from our phones or laptop

Then ChatGPT writes a letter in formal Portuguese, adds the Google Maps link with GPS coordinates, reverse looks up the address and adds it, attaches the photo of the problem and sends it to the local city council

Just a little one-shotted app to make our lives easier

items.title:
üö® OpenAI just launched ChatGPT Health.

This is for all of you who have asked ChatGPT to explain tha...
items.content:
üö® OpenAI just launched ChatGPT Health.

This is for all of you who have asked ChatGPT to explain that weird rash.
Or that lingering cough.
Or that itchy ear.

If you've been paying attention, this release isn't a surprise. @OpenAI spent all week running health-focused ads - a mom using AI to squeeze workouts into her schedule, a man using it to understand his health conditions, a woman checking if fabrics will trigger her eczema while shopping. The writing was on the wall. And if you read my 2026 AI predictions, you saw it there too.

WHAT IT ISüëá
ChatGPT Health is a dedicated space inside ChatGPT where you can connect medical records, Apple Health, MyFitnessPal, Peloton, and other wellness apps so AI can give you answers grounded in your actual health data. It can explain lab results, prep questions for a doctor visit, compare insurance plans (good god yes!!), and spot patterns in your sleep or activity over time.

Your health context stays within Health and doesn't transfer into your regular chats. OpenAI also partnered with b.well, the largest connected health data network in the US so far, for medical record access. They also (thankfully) built this new release with 260+ physicians over two years, so it can better handle escalation and safety caveats.

LIMITATIONS ‚ùå
Medical records and some app integrations are US-only. Apple Health requires iOS. Not available in EEA, Switzerland, or UK yet.

230 million people already ask ChatGPT health questions every week. The pot was already boiling. OpenAI is just building to meet demand.

Waitlist is open here: https://t.co/6BbWCYcQ0h

items.title: If you‚Äôve never written code before, this is for you. I‚Äôve just launched a course that shows you, in...
items.content:
If you‚Äôve never written code before, this is for you. I‚Äôve just launched a course that shows you, in less than 30 minutes, how to describe an idea for an app and build it with AI.

In this course, you'll build a working web application - a funny interactive birthday message generator that runs in your browser and can be shared with friends. You'll customize it by telling AI how you want it changed, and tweak it until it works the way you want. By the end, you'll have a repeatable process you can apply to build a wide variety of applications.

If you want to try vibe coding, this will be the best place to start! Further, you'll be able to use these techniques with whatever tool you're most comfortable with (like ChatGPT, Gemini, Claude, or others) -- we're vendor neutral. 

Skills you'll gain:
- How to build web apps with AI - zero coding skills needed
- How to fix and improve your creations by chatting with AI
- A simple process you can use to build other things you can dream up

Building with AI is one of the most fun things in the world. Please join me and take your first step! I think you will be surprised at what you can build. And if you're an experienced engineer, please share this with someone in your life who's been curious about building with AI.

Come build with me! https://t.co/q6gyzlxWFS

items.title:
I feel I'm operating at a much higher level when using Claude Code.

I've heard some people saying t...
items.content:
I feel I'm operating at a much higher level when using Claude Code.

I've heard some people saying that AI makes developers lazy, but that's not how I feel. I actually think I'm doing more work than ever before.

Of course, I'm writing fewer lines of code myself, but who cares? Most of this code I wrote in my sleep. It's boilerplate code that I've written a million times before, and now I have a little genie that does it for me.

The time I saved now went to reviewing Claude's code and working on specifications.

I'm spending much more time thinking about what I want to build and how I want to build it.

I think this is a huge win.

items.title:
A major breakthrough in reinforcement learning for robot training and the NeurIPS 2025 Best Paper.

...
items.content:
A major breakthrough in reinforcement learning for robot training and the NeurIPS 2025 Best Paper.

When training robots to walk, navigate, or manipulate objects, RL researchers have usually been using relatively shallow networks‚Äîtypically 2-5 layer MLPs mapping sensor readings to motor commands. Attempts to go deeper have failed because training becomes unstable and performance degrades.

Prior work attributed these failures to RL's sparse feedback: you might get one bit of information after thousands of decisions, so the ratio of signal to parameters is tiny.

In this paper, the authors show that the problem was architectural rather than fundamental. With residual connections, layer normalization, and Swish activation‚Äîsurprisingly standard elsewhere but not in control RL‚Äîyou can train networks up to 1000+ layers.

The paper demonstrates that gains from adding layers aren't gradual: at certain depth thresholds, agents acquire new behaviors. A simulated humanoid learns to walk upright only at 16 layers; at 256 layers, it learns to vault over walls.

Read online and ask questions when blocked: https://t.co/FUMFRxI9QW

Download the PDF: https://t.co/BvIgGj37Ot

The full list of the most important AI paper of 2025: https://t.co/fGEEd93F2A
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Andriy Burkov summarizes NeurIPS 2025 Best Paper on deep RL: standard architectural changes (residual connections, layer norm, Swish) enable 1000+ layer networks for robotics, unlocking emergent behaviors at depth thresholds
items.reasoning: Well-explained summary of major award-winning paper, high engagement (65K views), important finding for RL and robotics

items.title: Current LLMs all depend on tokenization, where raw text gets chopped into subword pieces from a fixe...
items.content:
Current LLMs all depend on tokenization, where raw text gets chopped into subword pieces from a fixed vocabulary before the model ever sees it. This is a brittle preprocessing step‚Äîthe same word gets split differently depending on context and rare words get shredded into smaller fragments compared to more common words.

Because tokens are atomic units to the model, it has no direct access to what characters compose them, which is why current models struggle with tasks like "how many r's are in strawberry" or "swap the first and last letter of this word."

BLT proposes working directly on bytes instead, but the obvious problem is that byte sequences are much longer than token sequences, making computation expensive.

The paper's solution is to dynamically group bytes into variable-length "patches" based on how predictable the next byte is: easy-to-predict regions (like the ending of a common word) get bundled into large patches that need little computation, while hard-to-predict regions (like the start of a new sentence) get small patches and more processing.

Unlike tokens, patches have no fixed vocabulary‚Äîany arbitrary byte sequence can become a patch, and the model builds a representation for it on the fly using a small encoder network that looks at the actual bytes. This means byte-level information is preserved throughout.

The result is an 8-billion parameter model that matches the performance of comparable tokenizer-based models while using significantly less computation at inference time, and it performs far better on character-level reasoning tasks (roughly 54% vs 27% on a character understanding benchmark).

Read actively on ChapterPal: https://t.co/3dWqRJsdYs

Download the PDF: https://t.co/fZhkZWuYW7
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Andriy Burkov explains BLT paper: working directly on bytes instead of tokens using dynamic patching based on predictability, achieving comparable results with better character-level reasoning
items.reasoning: Well-explained technical summary of important tokenization research, good engagement, novel approach to fundamental LLM architecture

items.title: Current chatbots that can generate both text and images typically do so by using two separately trai...
items.content:
Current chatbots that can generate both text and images typically do so by using two separately trained models: a language model for text and a diffusion model for images. The language model is finetuned to call a diffusion model when it thinks that the user wants an image as the response.

This paper shows how to train a single transformer to do both simultaneously. A 7B parameter model trained this way uses only 3% of compute needed to generate a dedicated diffusion model and generates images comparable in quality while also generating high-quality text, all within one unified architecture trained end to end.

ChapterPal: https://t.co/htAYyQwuPg

PDF: https://t.co/PVHUmomqb0
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Andriy Burkov summarizes paper on unified text-image generation: single 7B transformer trained end-to-end using 3% of diffusion model compute while matching quality
items.reasoning: Technical summary of significant multimodal AI efficiency paper

items.title: @juanstoppa Why are we fighting? Because robots don't really do that much yet. They aren't generaliz...
items.content:
@juanstoppa Why are we fighting? Because robots don't really do that much yet. They aren't generalized, so they can't do a variety of different tasks; they can only perform very specific tasks they've been trained for this year. That will change over time, but right now they're still quite limited. Fighting is something they can actually do.

The real reason for this is that fighting draws an audience:
1. In San Francisco, we had 4,000 people show up for robot fights, which helps sell robots to the public.
2. Part of why they're doing fights in China and here is to get people to see the robots, understand how they work, and get enthusiastic about them.
3. It serves as a forcing function on the industry to finish the robots and make them better.

Already, the industry has learned from these fights that the actuators overheat quite a bit. As a result, they've actually started changing robot designs to better compete in various robot sports.

It is a temporary phase. Robot fights are fun, but the goal is to use this as a forcing function to get to the next level and bring robots into people's homes. After all, watching a robot fight is much more entertaining than watching one fold laundry.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Detailed explanation of why robot fights exist: drawing audiences, demonstrating capabilities, serving as forcing function for industry improvement
items.reasoning: Insightful industry analysis on robotics development methodology, explains technical challenges like actuator overheating driving design changes

items.title:
Nobody teaches people how to actually build good software anymore.

Forget about theory. I'm talking...
items.content:
Nobody teaches people how to actually build good software anymore.

Forget about theory. I'm talking about the brutal reality of shipping AI systems that work in production.

You'll find a billion courses on Python syntax and how to call the OpenAI API, but nobody is teaching you how to design working software from first principles.

My 3-week cohort covers some of the most important topics you'll need to be successful:

1. How to frame problems (this alone will save you months)
2. How to build and evaluate RAG systems
3. How to build AI agents that don't fall apart
4. How to deploy and test in production
5. How to set up monitoring and observability from day one

More than 3,000 students have taken this program. Students from Google, AWS, Netflix, and many other top companies.

It's 20+ hours of live classes, 100+ coding assignments, and a complete end-to-end system you can use as a template for your own projects.

This class doesn't care what the book says. It focuses on experience building software that actually works.

The next cohort starts February 2, 2026.

You can join at https://t.co/iZifcK7UTF.

items.summary: Svpino promotes 3-week AI cohort covering problem framing, RAG systems, AI agents, deployment, monitoring. Claims 3000+ students from Google, AWS, Netflix.
items.reasoning: Promotional but outlines practical curriculum for production AI systems. Topics (RAG, agents, monitoring) reflect real industry needs. High engagement (158 likes, 22k views).

From Stadium Networks to AI Coaches: How Tech Is Redefining Sports

Stadiums aren‚Äôt venues anymore‚Äît...
items.content:
From Stadium Networks to AI Coaches: How Tech Is Redefining Sports

Stadiums aren‚Äôt venues anymore‚Äîthey‚Äôre living networks.

In my latest article I explore this together with @TMobileBusiness as a partner to unpack how it works.

What‚Äôs changing (fast):

‚Üí Connectivity = infrastructure. Ticketing, POS, broadcast, and crowd flow ride one wireless fabric. Less friction, faster ops, happier fans.

‚Üí Broadcast explodes in perspectives. More angles, less latency, interactive feeds you can steer.

‚Üí One network, many workloads. Dynamic bandwidth for what matters now‚Äîgate surges, replay reviews, merch spikes. 

‚Üí Partnerships accelerate breakthroughs. Ref-cams, AR graphics, on-body antennas‚Äînone of these ships without tight cross-team engineering.

Check out the full article: https://t.co/wrx6ctxUzd

Cc: @EvanKirstel | @Chels_LA | @antgrasso | @HaroldSinnott |

items.title:
üí¨ Do any of you still remember RealPlayer‚Ñ¢?

Back in the 1990s, websites were just text, links and i...
items.content:
üí¨ Do any of you still remember RealPlayer‚Ñ¢?

Back in the 1990s, websites were just text, links and if you were very lucky some images, but definitely NOT video or audio

Internet speeds were extremely slow (think 2.5kb/s, so about 10,000 times slower than an average connection now) so it was simply impossible or it'd take ages to load

RealPlayer changed that, they made a heavy compression codec for video and audio where a video could be just a few kilobytes, and with that it instantly became the first app that let people play real audio and video inside websites, it integrated into browsers like Netscape or Internet Explorer so people could embed video and audio on sites, and they did!

RealPlayer was so successful that by the year 2000 more than 85% of all audio or video content on the web was in the RealPlayer format

The app itself was free for people to use, and they made money by charging for the server software that would stream the video and audio

They IPO'd during the internet bubble of the late 90s and were valued at $550 million dollars, which would be $1B inflation-adjusted now, so they were a billion dollar company

(That internet bubble by the way has endless parallels with the AI bubble we're probably in today)

So why don't you hear about them these days anymore?

Well, Microsoft started bundling Windows Media Player with Windows, just like they did bundling Internet Explorer, and they gave away the server software for streaming Windows Media content (like .wma and .wmv) for free

This overnight nuked RealPlayer's business, so they sued Microsoft for unfair competition, they won in court in 2005, and Microsoft agreed to pay them $761 million to settle, so I think the founder still got rich from it

That same year in 2005, YouTube started and around 2008 the HTML standard added the <video> tag while making most video streaming tech open source, so it wasn't a business anymore

RealPlayer stayed public as a company though until actually recently, 2022, when the original founder @RobGlaser bought it back and took it private for about $25 million

Obviously nobody needs a video streaming app anymore, it's integrated in all platforms, software, and devices now, so now they seem to be focusing on "AI-powered facial recognition for security professionals"

On my site https://t.co/M1hEUBAynC I've installed RealPlayer for you go back into time and try and managed to the get streaming part working too, so you can listen to actual radio show from the 90s about UFOs at Roswell which I found on @textfiles's Discmaster archives

These days we all watch video on YouTube, Instagram, X and TikTok etc. but it all started with RealPlayer üòä
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Levelsio shares history of RealPlayer, noting parallels between 1990s internet bubble and current AI bubble. RealPlayer dominated then lost to Microsoft's free bundling.
items.reasoning: Historical tech perspective with explicit AI bubble comparison, very high engagement (2032 likes, 200k views), cautionary business lesson.

Also keep in mind that bullies tend to be craven and weak. So resisting them does not have to cost you much. They will retreat the moment they encounter any meaningfully costly level of resistance. All it takes is a tiny bit of courage.

items.title: Appeasing a bully never works. "I will give them what they're asking and they will go away" is not a...
items.content:
Appeasing a bully never works. "I will give them what they're asking and they will go away" is not a strategy, it's an invitation for the bully to go further.

They operate the following algorithm: "Did it work? then I keep pushing. Did I encounter any pushback? Then I back off"

They just keep going until they meet enough resistance. Resisting is the only way to make it stop.
items.author: @fchollet
items.summary: Fran√ßois Chollet elaborates on why appeasing bullies doesn't work
items.reasoning: Off-topic from AI/ML, general social commentary

items.title:
@iamsaura_ @javilopen @javilop @marclou @bryan_johnson This 1 week house thing is nice

But what we ...
items.content:
@iamsaura_ @javilopen @javilop @marclou @bryan_johnson This 1 week house thing is nice

But what we really need is get $100M investment, buy land and build cabins and infrastructure on it

In a place 30min from airport, where it's easy to get approval to build, with no shortage of workers

In a country where you can have a stable flow of people flying in

Healthmaxxing digital nomads is a nice market but in the end it's not big enough and you will end up pivoting to premium priced health retreats to be able to pay investors back

I bought a house and we installed a home gym, sauna, pool, jacuzzi, massage room etc. and it's great but was also expensive, and most people I know can't afford that

Which is where the market problem is, mostly only Americans or Australians etc have money to pay for this stuff

So putting it in Europe or Asia could work as a retreat

Michael from Dojo coworking in Canggu, Bali planned to build Dojo Village similar to this but gave up in the end

There's a lot of things to think about here but I think to not have it fail, get out of the dream phase quickly and see what the product and market is
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Levelsio discusses business model challenges for health-focused digital nomad retreats, suggesting need for $100M investment and premium pricing
items.reasoning: Business strategy discussion but not AI-related, provides entrepreneurial insights
